lines.code: """ Returns the first item in the list for which function(item) is True, None otherwise.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Functions take Sentence objects, see pattern.text.tree.Sentence and pattern.text.parsetree().
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: INDICATIVE  = "indicative"  # They went for a walk.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: IMPERATIVE  = "imperative"  # Let's go for a walk!
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: CONDITIONAL = "conditional" # It might be nice to go for a walk when it stops raining.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: SUBJUNCTIVE = "subjunctive" # It would be nice to go for a walk sometime.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: return word.type.startswith(("VB","MD")) and (word.chunk is None or word.chunk.type.endswith("VP"))
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: return [w for w in sentence[i:j or len(sentence)] if verb(w)]
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ The imperative mood is used to give orders, commands, warnings, instructions,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: or to make requests (if used with "please").
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: It is marked by the infinitive form of the verb, without "to":
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: raise TypeError("%s object is not a parsed Sentence" % repr(S.__class__.__name__))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if S.subjects and s(S.subjects[0]) not in ("you", "yourself"):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # The subject can only identify as "you" (2sg): "Control yourself!".
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # A conjunction can also indicate conditional mood.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if s(w) in ("do", "let") and w == verbs(S)[0]:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if s(w) in ("will", "shall") and i > 0 and s(S[i-1]) == "you" and not verbs(S,0,i):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Break on any other verb form.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #  "Do it if you think it is necessary.", # False
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #  "I hope you will help me.",            # False
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #  "I can help you if you let me."):      # False
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ The conditional mood is used to talk about possible or imaginary situations.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: It is marked by the infinitive form of the verb, preceded by would/could/should:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: "we should be going", "we could have stayed longer".
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: With predictive=False, sentences with will/shall need an explicit if/when/once-clause:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: - "I will help you if you pay me" => speculative.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Sentences with can/may always need an explicit if-clause.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: raise TypeError("%s object is not a parsed Sentence" % repr(S.__class__.__name__))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if i > 0 and (s(S[i-1]) in ("i", "it", "he", "she") or S[i-1].type == "NN"):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # "As if it were summer already." => subjunctive (wish).
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if s(w) == "ought" and i < len(S) and s(S[i+1]) == "to":
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if s(w) in ("will", "shall", "'ll") and i > 0 and s(S[i-1]) == "you" and not verbs(S,0,i):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # "I will help you when I get back." => speculative.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: for cc in ("if", "when", "once", "as soon as", "assuming", "provided that", "given that"):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #  "I hope you will help me.",       # True (predictive)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #  "I can help you if you let me."): # True
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ The subjunctive mood is a classical mood used to express a wish, judgment or opinion.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: It is marked by the verb wish/were, or infinitive form of a verb
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: "It is recommended that he bring his own computer."
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: raise TypeError("%s object is not a parsed Sentence" % repr(S.__class__.__name__))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if s(w) == "hope" and i > 0 and s(S[i-1]) in ("i", "we"):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if s(w) == "were" and i > 0 and (s(S[i-1]) in ("i", "it", "he", "she") or S[i-1].type == "NN"):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # "It is as though she were here." => counterfactual.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # "I propose that you be on time."
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: elif s(w) == "is" and 0 < i < len(S)-1 and s(S[i-1]) == "it" \
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # "It is important that you be there." => but you aren't (yet).
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: elif s(w) == "is" and 0 < i < len(S)-3 and s(S[i-1]) == "it" \
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # "It is a good idea that you be there."
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # With classical=False, "It is important that you are there." passes.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # This is actually an informal error: it states a fact, not a wish.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if v and classical is True and v and v.type == "VB":
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if v and classical is False:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: epistemic_VB = { # wish => feel => believe => seem => think => know => prove + THAT
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: epistemic_RB = { # unlikely => supposedly => maybe => probably => usually => clearly => definitely
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: -0.50: d("but that", "but this", "have sought", "might have", "seems to"),
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: -0.25: d("may also", "may be", "may have", "may have been", "some have", "sort of"),
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: +0.00: d("been argued", "believed to", "considered to", "claimed to", "is considered", "is possible",

lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: "many modern", "many people", "most people", "some people", "some cases", "some studies",
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: +0.50: d("in several", "is likely", "many of", "many other", "of many", "of the most", "such as",
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: +0.75: d("almost always", "and many", "and some", "around the world", "by many", "in many", "in order to",
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Returns the sentence's modality as a weight between -1.0 and +1.0.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Currently, the only type implemented is EPISTEMIC.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Epistemic modality is used to express possibility (i.e. how truthful is what is being said).
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # A Sentence is expected but a string given.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if i > 0 and s(S[i-1]) in MODIFIERS:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Numbers, citations, explanations make the sentence more factual.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return 1.0 # No modal verbs/adverbs used, so statement must be true.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Celle, A. (2009). Hearsay adverbs and modality, in: Modality in English, Mouton.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Allegedly, presumably, purportedly, ... are in the negative range because
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # they introduce a fictious point of view by referring to an unclear source.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Tseronis, A. (2009). Qualifying standpoints. LOT Dissertation Series: 233.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Following adverbs are not epistemic but indicate the way in which things are said.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # 1) actually, admittedly, avowedly, basically, bluntly, briefly, broadly, candidly,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #    confidentially, factually, figuratively, frankly, generally, honestly, hypothetically,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #    in effect, in fact, in reality, indeed, literally, metaphorically, naturally,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #    of course, objectively, personally, really, roughly, seriously, simply, sincerely,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # 2) bizarrely, commendably, conveniently, curiously, disappointingly, fortunately, funnily,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #    happily, hopefully, illogically, interestingly, ironically, justifiably, justly, luckily,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #    oddly, paradoxically, preferably, regretfully, regrettably, sadly, significantly,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #    strangely, surprisingly, tragically, unaccountably, unfortunately, unhappily unreasonably
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f
